setup.question: The explorers note the metal band around the city and assume that it is there for defense.  What is ironic about the way they opt to proceed?
answers: They feel that even though the city could be defended, they do not feel that it will match the defenses they bring with them, thus proceeding.
They do not believe that the defense mechanism will be engaged, so they venture on.

Text.text: It seems slightly more likely that they don't expect the defense to be engaged, compared to the cities defenses being stronger than their own.
The team is confident that the weapons they brought with them would defend them against whatever the city brings. As they move deeper into the city:
The explorers are venturing into an mysterious city on the south pole of an otherwise essentially barren planet:
. The men don't think the city is inhabited, though they're creeped out:

(note "were".)

This is shortly before they go in (at 739â€“744). When they go in, nobody explicitly said why they proceeded despite the metal band. It's implied that go in bc they don't expect anything to happen. They have guns, but they aren't mentioned at the time and have no relevance to a city-level defense system.
A: seems like the guns quote comes much later - is that actually relevant for their decision to enter the city?

They explicitly mention being aware that the city is defended by the metal band and yet they decide to enter. Nowhere is it mentioned that they do not expect the metal band to work. Considering they brought their weapons with them (see previous quote), we can assume that they believe they are equipped to face anything that might oppose them in the city.
No, it's not relevant to their decision to enter the city. Indeed, Debater A's quote is the first mention of guns at all, and they enter much earlier (

). Plus, the question is asking what's ironic about their decision. The irony in answer B comes from the fact (which I really should have mentioned earlier, sorry) that the defense system DID engage despite the city being so old:
, trapping some of the men in the city. Their guess is that it's an
which was activated presumably by them bringing traces of radiation with them.

Seem pretty clear that B is correct - the evidence A used comes much later than when they enter the city, so it doesn't seem like a clear factor in their decision, and my prior on them assuming the defense mechanism won't be engaged because the planet is abandoned and the city is old is very high.
there's like no ev from A although admittedly the B ev doesn't all seem super contextualized.

answers.judge strategies: I asked a follow-up question about the relevance of debater A's quote (because I suspected it wasn't actually relevant). Debater A said it was relevant but didn't give a convincing account, and debater B agreed that it wasn't relevant.
answers.reason for outcome: I believe I got the right answer because there was little *relevant* evidence for the incorrect answer. There was some actually, but it came much later in the story than it probably would have needed to to serve as good information.
It was difficult to lie for my answer
Mostly Debater A had very little evidence to go off of in the story (the closest thing was guns).
b had more ev that fit, a had nothing and lowkey gave up
